commentBody: a hat?

What a fun portrayal of a wonderful painting.
I remember seeing it come to life years ago, with Bernadette Peters and Mandy Patinkin.
He sang with a Staten Island school kids choir at NYC Mayor Mamdani‚Äôs inauguration recently.
Fun puzzle. Fun animation when completed. Enjoyed the theme. Thanks, Joseph, for a wonderful puzzle! Happy Wednesday, y‚Äôall!

This one‚Äôs for you, Andrzej! A whole puzzle (not just one entry) for you. 

As for me, the fun of this puzzle lies only if you‚Äôre familiar with the work. And although I‚Äôm sure there will be many who say they are familiar with SONDHEIM‚Äôs work, I am not one of them. And the joke fell especially flat because I don‚Äôt think of the secret message as a ‚Äúfamous lyric,‚Äù as Jim Horne at xwordinfo.com called it, because it was the first time I‚Äôd ever come across it. 

And I reiterate, I‚Äôm realize a lot of you have. But I guarantee there will be a whole lot of others who haven‚Äôt. 

So a perfectly cromulent puzzle, I suppose, but no joy for me this time.

I liked today's puzzle, even though the theme is completely out of my wheelhouse it didn't stop me from solving it.  I still don't get the connect the dots.  "LOOK IM A DEA HAT"?  I'm sure that means something to the people who've seen the musical but not to me.

Good cluing in general.  Figure-outable clues without relying on proper nouns and niche trivia.  I got the STEVEN SONDHEIM clue with only like five crossing clues just recognizing the name.

ELIOT/SOU I got by trying all letters.  I probably should have thought of ELIOT but no clue about what SOU means.

Poor Andrzej is going to be exposed to more knowledge about Broadway musicals.  

Musicals, movies, sports, minor tv characters, poets.  This one has something to get almost everyone riled up.  I enjoyed it though, as all that was in my wheelhouse.
Cute puzzle.  A Wednesday PB, for me, which I guess means I‚Äôve spent too many nights around the piano at Marie‚Äôs Crisis!
This page's URL should be https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/13/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2026-01-14.html. (It's missing the "0" in "01-14".)

Twisty clever. Would've preferred to do as instructed, connect the letters and make the hat, but it did it by itself. Oh well. Que seurat seurat. 

Poetry lesson, January 14. "Burnt Norton" is where that line first appeared, a long poem, first of the Four Quartets,  published in slim volumes by Faber & Faber between 1941 & 1945. Those unfamiliar with Burnt Norton might think it's a reference to some English hamlet bombed by the Germans. Actually it's the name of a large manor house in Gloucestershire with splendid gardens, famous for its roses and its complex of paths and byways. Eliot visited there in 1934 and saw in the diverging paths a metaphor for time and its phenomenological paradoxes:

Time present and time past
Are both perhaps present in time future,
And time future contained in time past.
If all time is eternally present
All time is unredeemable.
What might have been is an abstraction 
Remaining a perpetual possibility
Only in a world of speculation.
What might have been and what has been
Point to one end, which is always present.
Footfalls echo in the memory
Down the passage which we did not take
Towards the door we never opened
Into the rose-garden. My words echo
Thus, in your mind.
***
Thus are we drawn into the garden's world. All that philosophical abstraction vanishes, replaced by lyrical imagism, for what is an image but a vortex in space and time? (Ezra Pound's definition). War does appear, how could it not? Eliot ponders how war warps time, and vice versa.
'look imadeah at?' 'look ima deahat?' whatever i finally got it! nice animation, nice puzzle (even though i was not familiar with the song or musical)...encore! have a great wednesday eveeyone

3:43 under my average. As a theater brat from utero this was in my wheelhouse. I enjoy a good toe tapper, but as I am frequently one of the performers creating the music, I‚Äôm more a head bopper. Two pieces of music in one group‚Äôs repertoire that are really head bopping toe tappers are medleys. Mancini! Opening with The Pink Panther and closing with Peter Gunn. And the second? Can‚Äôt Buy Me Love! Love me some Beatles. Never been in or seen Sunday in the park with George.

PSHAW?! I know it's a valid word but can we apply a bit of GUCCI to these olde tyme wordes and refresh them with more modern lingo please? I can't remember a time when I used it as I tend to being a bit more colourful in expressing myself at times. Not my Dad - he'd use something like 'piffle' or 'bazfaz' instead.

LOOK I found a way to get to the Wordplay column üò¨ I don‚Äôt understand why this has happened so frequently this year, but here we are. 

Some lively entries today. I liked LOOKIE LOOS and PSHAW as well as I‚ÄôM SCARED üôÑ. I can picture my kids saying it to me as I threaten some sort of punishment that they could not care less about ü§£

Cool animation at the end. Thanks Joseph!

Completed in 45% less time than average.  Some of the speed may be attributed to using a computer rather than my phone.  Had no idea what "look I made a hat" meant until I Googled it.  

Costs before RATES.
Situationship is news to me.
For whatever reason, PSHAW is a great word.  

And now for an overdose on puzzle-inspired  puns:
Walking through poison ivy is a RASH decision.
Entomologists have discovered there are fifty ways to leave your LARVA.
Had sighs of relief when I was able to come up with 53D.
Oh, man, how did I end up in this sultanate near Yemen?

Hats off to SONDHIEM!!

The hat was a wonderful treat.  Nice to see the Magnificent Seven. 

Someone tell me a joke. We gotta keep our spirits up around here.
That was a lot of fun, especially since the final bit worked on two levels. The constructor could have done more, but that would have risked being a hat on a hat.
now ill wait patiently for a setter from my planet to do the "LOOK I HIT FOR THE CYCLE" puzzle...
What the hat! I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll ever chatch up on all the Broadway musicals. Thanks for the fun puzzle, anyway!

Link to wordplay column from puzzle still not fixed.

"Look, I made an app link that works" not consistently said at the NYT.
Thanks for the Mandy Patinkin link.   I saw the show years ago in a Milwaukee regional theater and was already familiar with the painting.  So this was a great puzzle for me.

As you can probably imagine, I was not excited by the theme.

The many trivial unknowns in the otherwise straightforward fill made the solving experience quite unpleasant. I missed a letter being wrong in MIRACLE-G_O. The cross of LASH I got after wrongly guessing G(L)O didn't make sense with its clue, but since (L)ASH is not meaningless and MIRACLE GLO looks good enough, I missed it and ended up checking the puzzle.

It wasn't an offensively bad puzzle but it gave me zero pleasure to solve it because of who I am.
Just GUCCI. ENCORE! ‚ù§Ô∏è

Loved, loved, loved it.  And i loved the graphic of the hat making itself, even though the Notes to the puzzle said I was going to have to draw it myself. 
Also, SONDHEIM created many a game or puzzle by himself.  He particularly created cryptics according to what i've read.

I never have heard of the musical in question, which was alright because the downs filled in the blanks nicely. I vibed with the constructor today, but new terms for me in "LOOKIE LOOS" being window shoppers- I've heard associate the term with neighborhood gossips or rubber neckers. Also have never heard "GUCCI" used for anything other than "good" or "okay".

Other than those, fun and engaging with a perfect difficulty for a Wednesday I thought.
I felt left out, having never heard the song. Oh well.

Neat puzzle. Even Stephen Sondheim, not having heard of him, I was able to figure out with crossings but‚Ä¶ NEE? Once called?

I don‚Äôt get it. It was really hard to start anything in that top left corner, I eventually had to look at the column for PABA to get the juices flowing.
SOU, as uttered at least once in another musical, Les Miserables. Intentional reference or happy accident? Either way, a GUCCI puzzle for a happy Wednesday!

Pretty niche theme, but one that is close to my heart. Love the musical, have watched the recorded version several times with Mandy Patinkin and Bernadette Peters (you can probably stream it or watch it online). Stephen Sondheim is an acquired taste and it‚Äôs definitely not a TOETAPPER, but it‚Äôs a very beautiful and evocative show about the nature of art and probably my second favorite Sondheim musical (behind Company and above Into the Woods). I highly recommend it. ‚ÄúLook I Made a Hat‚Äù is also the name of Sondheim‚Äôs biography, so it‚Äôs not just a random lyric but a meaningful concept of art creating something that didn‚Äôt exist before (like a crossword puzzle, in fact).
Anyway, not a bad crossword even apart from the theme, with some unexpected clues, and I enjoyed it.
Last comment just to nip some nitpickers in the bud‚Äîyes the name of the painter of ‚ÄúA Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte‚Äù is Georges Seurat (with an S at the end) but the musical is also about his (fictional) great-grandson who is named George and that is whom the title refers. Also, if you are Star Trek fan and watch the original version, you can get a glimpse of Brent Spiner (Data) in a supporting role; I‚Äôm afraid that probably won‚Äôt be enough to tempt Andrzej, though.

LOOK I‚ÄôM A DEA HAT? What the heck is a DEA hat?

Oh, LOOK I MADE A HAT. Okay fine, but so what? I‚Äôm guessing it relates to Sunday in the Park with George. 

I prefer puzzles where the theme/trick can help you solve the puzzle. Not some reference to some rando musical that I‚Äôve never heard of. 

Other than that, not too hard, not too easy. A good enough Wednesday puzzle for me.

Since the circled letters really didn't seem all that necessary to get the puzzle, and were more for fun, I didn't mind so much that I ended up confusedly asking, "look, I'm a Dea hat?"

Heard of the musical, but just haven't seen it. Though now reading the wiki while trying to find what song the lyric had to be from to find the correct words, I'm not a lot more interested. Love this painting.

Otherwise, this was a really nice Wednesday puzzle.
The link in the app doesn‚Äôt work. It directs to https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/13/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2026-01-14.html And thus arriving here is circuitous. The NYT is living in the past

Im confused I have filled out the puzzle and I keep being told it‚Äôs wrong. I compared letter by letter to the answer key and it‚Äôs identical. Cause I was losing my mind I had AI compare it too. It‚Äôs the same. Is there a trick to getting it completed? I‚Äôm fairly new to this. Thanks so much.

My favorite fact about STORKS - hold on, you won‚Äôt believe this if you haven‚Äôt heard it already - is that people in Europe didn‚Äôt know where all the birds went in winter time until one spring day in 1822, when a stork came to Germany with a large African arrow embedded in its chest, and they started to put two and two together. Until then, nobody knew for sure, and there were some crazy theories doing the rounds, like birds go to the moon in winter, or turn into other animals. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pfeilstorch https://www.audubon.org/magazine/what-gruesome-stork-taught-us-about-bird-migration
Just came here to say that ENDIVES are not green

When I started doing NYT crosswords in February last year, I was averaging more than an hour for Wednesday to Saturday crosswords and more than two hours on Sunday. These required a lot of searching for answers on the net. I have now managed to get my Wednesday average below half an hour and I didn't need use any look ups. This is now fairly common for me.

As far as the theme is concerned, I 'm afraid I am not a fan of Sondheim. The only way I would pay to hear anything he was connected with is if some highlights from Westside Story were part of an orchestral concert I wanted to go to. And that's because he only wrote the words for that musical. That is not an art-form I am keen on but I accept that the NYT is going to have a fair number of clues related to it.

I'm not a fan of musicals, and know nothing about "Sunday in the Park With George", but I did get a kick out of the revealer.  I drew it and laughed at the absurdity of me making a hat, or at least a representation of a hat.

I had heard of the title of the show before, but never made the Seurat connection until reading the comments.

Oh, *that* Georges!

Don't know the song, 
but thoroughly enjoyed the gentle solve.

Opie the pup was (apparently)
*not* ready for bed when he went into his crate
so I stayed up quite late with him, 
and the world is...fuzzy.

Now to look for Andrzej's sentimental
waltz down musical memory lane,,,

A very niche puzzle that did not float my boat. I have heard of the musical, and most people know of Stephen Sondheim. But too many conversational phrases, too many words I never heard of, like GUCCI as a slang word, the comedy team of Key and PEELE, and ultimately, the revealer. So I finished the puzzle without any lookups, connected the dots, got the phrase LOOK I MADE A HAT, and so what? It was meaningless to me, and if those of you do know that phrase and are able to relate it to the musical in the theme, my hat's off to you. But I do think that most will be scratching their bare heads at this one. Congrats to the ones who got it all. 

The entire puzzle left me cold, and I found no joy in finishing it successfully. Just my two SOUs worth.

Good puzzle--don't know anything about the musical but sounds fun. I thought the revealer was LOOK I'M DEATH because my eyes were faster than my brain.

Anyways--OK and OKAY in a puzzle. Sigh. Not a fan, but et tu emus.
OK THEN
Not a fan of the theme at all, which was niche. The big reveal is a ‚Äúhat‚Äù and some lyric about making a hat. Super gimmicky.

If 10D was clued simply as [You frighten me!], would that suggest we were living in scarier times, or just duller ones?


Didn‚Äôt know the lyric, but the puzzle tickled my fancy.
Gucci gucci goo(d).

So was it too obvious to mention that Seurat developed Pointillism?
...I connected those dots.
Hats off to the constructor JG

Another Wednesday In The Puzzle with Joseph, now with five of his six NYT puzzles appearing on that day. And another Joseph puzzle with an accent on grid art. His first Times puzzle has the most adorable black-square crossword image I‚Äôve ever seen (warning, the two following links show completed puzzle) -- https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/16/2022 -- and for his second, he actually made a hat! -- https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/18/2023 . I love Sondheim‚Äôs originality, wordplay, and non-hackneyed melodies, so this puzzle kindled good feelings. I‚Äôm also a fan of impressive puzzle-making, and this junk-lite grid with its two spanners and incredibly constricting symmetrical hat is just that. But the highlight for me was Sam‚Äôs posting of Mandy Patinkin singing ‚ÄúFinishing the Hat‚Äù, which I found stunning and mesmerizing. And thus, a happy-button puzzle for me, for which, Joseph, I‚Äôm highly grateful ‚Äì thank you!
Marvelous.

Any puzzle with Stephen Sondheim and one of his wonderful musicals in it is a winner in my book.
One of the giants of the American musical theater, Sondheim was innovative and dramatically altered the course of the Broadway musical, much like Rodgers and Hammerstein, Cole Porter, and today‚Äôs Lin Manuel-Miranda.  If it makes him more palatable to puzzle solvers here, he constructed cryptic puzzles for New York Magazine early in his career.

The puzzle, for me, was fine, but the added graphic made it a little more interesting.
Cute idea, each individual clue wasn't Wednesday level difficult.

As a Sondheim fan, I enjoyed that especially. We had tickets to see Jake Gyllenhaal in the show in the West End, but it was cancelled during Covid. Perhaps this puzzle is the closest I'll ever get to seeing 'Sunday'...(!)

I've never heard of this musical, and don't usually like musicals. 

But hey I liked the puzzle! 

And I appreciate 'niche' puzzles which go outside my usual areas of interest, and let me learn something new! 

And gimmicks are fun: it's hard to imagine not being at least slightly amused by a hat suddenly activated! Good job, nice surprise for a Wednesday grid! Hats off!

Yes, I know STEPHEN SONDHEIM.  Yes, I've heard of "Sunday in the Park with George(s)".  Yes, I know the painting.
But I've never heard of "Finishing the Hat", and I don't know the line "LOOK, I MADE A HAT".
So, the puzzle ends on what can only be called a disappointing note, for me at least.

And LOOK!  An animation of a rather sad-looking HAT!  So who cares if the link doesn't work.  The tech people have given us enough, no?

Fortunately I didn't need the theme or the artwork to solve this puzzle, since I've never seen "Sunday in the Park With George" and the famous lyric was a complete unknown to me.

PABA was also a mystery, but maybe it will come to me later.

This was one of the finest connect-the-dots homage puzzles that I've seen recently.

This just made me cranky.  Finished, saw the hat, but have no recollection or recognition of the circled lyric fragment. Meh.

Okay, I'll go watch Sam's link to the song.
But get off my lawn.

Quick anecdote: since I've never heard of the musical or the song, when the hat activated, I followed the letters and first read the phrase as 'I'm a DEA hat.' 

I wondered what a DEA hat looked like, and why this would be showcased in the puzzle...
Did anyone else search for an image of a DEA hat?
Enjoyable puzzle today.   I did better than i expected.

I‚Äôm pretty knowledgeable about broadway musicals (my sisters and I used to belt out Funny Girl songs) but I have never heard of this one.  When I finished the puzzle I thought the picture was a truck or some kind of vehicle.  But I‚Äôm never one to complain about not knowing something in a crossword.  I just chalk it up to education. Puzzle itself was enjoyable in and of itself.
I gather most if not all online solvers did *not* have to connect the circled letters as per the note; the app did it for you.

A fitting tribute to a Broadway composer who was also incredibly fond of puzzles. We just picked up a copy of Barry Joseph‚Äôs ‚ÄúMatching Minds with Sondheim,‚Äù which includes some he devised. And considering that ‚ÄúSunday‚Äù won the Pulitzer Prize for Drama, I‚Äôm quite surprised at the number of commenters who are not familiar with one of his greatest works. Find the ‚ÄúGreat Performances‚Äù broadcast if you can.

tHAT was not wHAT i was expecting...
Never saw the play (doubt it was ever made into a flick), never heard any of the songs from it that I can recall--which is a bit unusual, because popular numbers from musicals get aired often...  Maybe Steve L or Barry Ancona will post a link...

I have never see/heard LOOKIE LOOS... but I think vendors should not be ungrateful.  Lookers turn into buyers if the mdse is worthwhile, unusual, useful, interesting, attractive, desirable...  and the more LOOKIE LOOS you attract, the more likely that might happen.  Don't sneer at potential customers, in other words; it ill becomes you!

OKAY THEN....on with the day.

. . .

George and Dot.
Is what we got.
Chapeau. Let's go!

. . .

Well... managed to work it all out, but must confess I was not familiar enough with the various theme answers to put it all together. No big deal. And.. there was another STEPHENSONDHEIM puzzle. A Tuesday from February 8, 2005 by Stephen Budiansky. STEPHENSONDHEIM was one theme answer in that one. The other two theme answers were... SENDINTHECLONES and ABUOYLIKETHAT Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/8/2005&g=17&d=A ...

This is only one of a small handful of puzzles I ever went and read the comments because I did not understand the "Look I made a hat".  I love the creative aspect -great puzzle! First time I ever read the creators notes, so true! And I will add that I read the lyrics to the song Finished a Hat, and they compel me to stop with the puzzle obsession and go make breakfast for my spouse ; )

"Famous"? You keep using that word. I do not think it means what you think it means.

Sure it was niche, but it was my niche. Hope it wasn't too painful for the rest of you.

I remember watching the first season of "Chicago Hope" just to see Mandy Patinkin. He was a surgeon who sometimes broke out into song, which I think is pretty cool as long as it's not your surgeon.




Hats off to Claudette Colvin.
I liked him much better in The Princess Bride. Good singer tho.

I tend to recoil when a puzzle sacrifices pleasant fill to accommodate a theme and a gimmick and today sadly was no different.

We can throw LOOKIELOOS in the dumpster and bury it, editors. 

Hope the Sondheim fans out there enjoyed this one.

I recognized immediately that it was a musical theater theme and began to panic, but this was supremely doable even for someone like me, who watches a musical about once a decade. And I got to make a hat!

Bravo, Joseph Gangi, and I hope for an ENCORE!
Nice tribute to the famous cryptic crossword constructor, STEPHEN SONDHEIM.
So I guess that graphic puts the lid on it.

Initially thought it was "Look I'm a DEA hat".

Seemed an odd lyric for a Sondheim musical.

I went to a public elementary school in Chicago with a vibrant arts program. In eighth grade I would journey via train to the Art Institute of Chicago once per week for a class. There I learned that the famous Georges Seurat painting ‚ÄúA Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte‚Äù was the inspiration for a Broadway musical called ‚ÄúSunday in the Park with George‚Äù. We also were each tasked with finding a painting that inspired us and using it as the basis to write a short play. More than 40 years later, I still think about it when I look at paintings and try to imagine the rich inner lives of the people captured in a two-dimensional work of art. Kudos to Sondheim and Seurat for partnering across centuries and continuing to inspire.

Broadway themes usually set me up for a slow solve since I know nothing about that world. This one wasn't too bad though! Finished significantly faster than my average without knowing who that guy is.

Loved the cross of ENDIVE and ENCORE.

Decades ago when I worked in Geneva, I had to adapt to hearing the words ENCORE and voila so frequently.  For an ignorant American like me, sounded too fancy.

Seemed like the cafeteria served ENDIVE all winter‚Ä¶ nearly the only green vegetable.  Got the blank stare when I pronounced it the American way.  But I hardly knew what it even was.  It was the only green thing in a serving tray, ready to be dished out, at the cafeteria.

Now it is the French pronunciation that is imprinted forever in my head, and I get the blank stare here.

Fun puzz! A little weird to have OK and OKAY in the same grid but I‚Äôm sure weirder things have happened. SONDHEIM was a genius who was not only a great musical composer but a great composer and lyricist period. As a songwriter I draw a lot of inspo from his work. My three faves are Company (check out the DA Pennebaker doc if you haven‚Äôt), Pacific Overtures, and Sweeney Todd. Company is probably number one since it‚Äôs basically the story of my life. But seeing Pacific Overtures with George Takei 1.5 times in 2017 was a bucket list item.

Eh....

I hate to say it but I found today's puzzle a tab too easy for a Wednesday. One of my fastest Wednesday solves. 

 I'm an enormous fan of Stephen Sondheim (and was lucky enough in my life to the original Broadway productions of Sweeney Todd, Passion, Into the Woods and Sunday in the Park with George.  And, yes, I guess that's a boast. Though it also means I'm a little old.)  On the other hand, to my eternal shame, at some point in my adult life I came to realize that the "depressing/not really very good" Broadway show that my Mom and Dad had walked out of at intermission when I was a child was actually the original  "Follies"!   I don't want to say that I love them less for this act of criminally bad taste, but well I guess everyone discovers that their parents were flawed and damaged in some way. LOL. 

Anyway - so I was excited when I saw this was a Sondheim-themed puzzle but a little disppointed by the relative sparsity of Sondheim-based answers.  (Although to be fair, a Sondheim-theme really calls out for a Sunday puzzle.)  I didn't even see the "LOOK I MADE A HAT" reference until I'd finished the entire board.

Given that fact, I don't think I can really attribute my speed today to my familiarity with Sondheim as much what I think is otherwise a sort of simple solve.

Loved this puzzle.  It reminded me of Lin Manuel Miranda‚Äôs 2008 Tony acceptance speech for In the Heights, in which Miranda rapped his thanks,including an homage to Sondheim:

‚ÄúMr. Sondheim, look.  I made a hat where there never was a hat.  It‚Äôs a Latin hat at that.‚Äù :)

Have a good day, all!  (Deb, I hope you‚Äôre enjoying your next chapter!)
Mortifyingly, I looked up IMADEAHAT.  Brain stuck on almost "death" in the middle.
Out of dots, no less!

Coincidentally, I was inspired to look up ‚ÄúA Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte‚Äù last night when it was referenced in a book I‚Äôm reading. Life‚Äôs little synchronicities never cease to tickle me.
Pretty cool puzzle today.  Thanks for creating/publishing it.
‚ÄúDoes anyone still wear a hat?‚Äù
What a fitting tribute to Mr. Sondheim and his amazing body of work. Nice puzzle, Joseph!
Never heard of the musical before but the animation at the end was cute

I love art, and I love theatre...all is well. 
Hadn't thought of "pshaw" in a while - thanks for that!

Struggled with the middle - confidently entering BRUINS (43A) ( :|  ...  in my defense it is a sports arena that has 'Garden' in the name) and CAPTAINS (25D) was unhelpful for me. 

Fun puzzle though!
unbelievably delightful!! Originally had sondheimMUSICAL at 17A and had to change it when I got to the bottom of the grid
How fortuitous, Ariana Grande and Jonathan Bailey have JUST been announced TODAY as the leads in the "Sunday in the Park" London revival! Enjoyed this lovely jaunt today :)
Showbiz trivia, oh joy.
I love to this puzzle! It was so clever and I loved the hat.
Wonderful Wednesday grid! Thank you, Joseph Gangi -- I really enjoyed the visual upon completion and appreciate the clever thought and effort that went into its creation!

I had no problem solving the whole puzzle but had no idea what a hat had to do with it having never seen the play.  Had to come to Wordplay for an explanation.  This confirms my belief that crossword creators are of the mistaken belief that I have also seen every Disney Princess movie and know all the princesses by name.
Learned another cutesy neologism: Lookie-loos. Who knew?
Probably the silliest theme I've seen. Had a good chuckle.
Hah! That was very silly, and fun. Thanks Joseph!
GENIUS!!! No need to "send in the clowns" on this brilliant crossword!  Sondheim would be proud.

The theme was lost on me to enjoy the puzzle as much as others. I PALE in comparison to others on Broadway subjects and know nothing about STEPHEN SONDHEIM. However, bravo to the constructor for creating a puzzle where the crosses help those not versed on the theme.
What a lovely gift at the end -- I'm a big Sondheim fan and didn't cotton on to the hat reference until it was animated. Well done, and hats off ;)

Brilliant, and so much fun. What a great tribute to the great Sondheim. Also, thank you so much for the Mandy Patinkin clip -- from a fan of both men who has somehow managed to never have seen "Sunday in the Park with George."

Look I made a hat???? 
I get that someone out there or perhaps many someones know the reference, and many more once learning of it find it somehow instructive or inspirational. 
I find it one of the all time great let downs. I didn't exactly labor my utmost to solve this puzzle, but I was hoping for some sort of payoff I could relate to. You made a hat. How tedious. 
Now, I know the online world. If you say something you find true and express your positive regard for it, you get love back. But if you express something true and express a negative view of it, you get ad hominem attacks and calumny. I am resigned to this fate, fire away.
This may have been worse than one of the Wicked puzzles. Oh well.

I thought the hat was darn cute, even though I haven't seen the show. 
I saw Mandy Patinkin in Evita back around 1980. I was a college student and got a cheap last-minute ticket for a seat in the first row. Patinkin, as Che Guevara, spent much of the show at the spot on stage right in front of me. It was memorable.

1/14/26. 8 down. 
an alum is by no means a grad. definitely an attendee. very weak clue.

Apparently the Emus didn't like my first attempt, so here's lightly edited retry:

I'm late to the party, having been busy at 10pm, then asleep till this morning, but let me add to the chorus of negativity about the theme. 

I completed the puzzle, and since I use the Android app, saw it draw something while spelling out an an at first uninterpretable phrase ("I'M ADEAH AT"? "I MAD EAHAT"? "I'M A DE AHAT"?) before finally getting "I MADE A HAT", and going ... Huh? What has that got to do with anything?!? 

So tap the I button to get to the column for an explanation. OH. OKAY THEN, it's a line from a song in the musical. One line, from a song I've never heard, from a musical I'd never before heard of. Talk about the epitome of trivia! Annoying, but it is what it is. (I Watched the embedded video, and could get nothing from it out of context).

My friend Wilbur is a big fan of post-impressionist French art, a taste which his wife Katherine dies not share. On a recent trip to Chicago, I met up with the pair, and we spent an afternoon at the Art Institute, where Wilbur had never been.

Scarce had we entered the museum, when he exclaimed:
"Kay! Seurat! Seurat!"
To which she replied 
"Whatever, Wilby . . ."

As the author of a recent book on Sondheim, his games, and his crossword puzzles, I was excited to see this puzzle. As this is still news to most, I‚Äôll share a little known history behind the song Finishing the Hat. It could have been called Finishing the Game. In 1965 his friend Phyllis Newman had a show flop out of town. He asked what he could do and she said make a game for me when I return. He designed The Murder Game in an overnight 11-hour creative fugue. It was a hit (and has its own story). In the early 80s, creating Sunday in the Park With George, he wanted to write a song about that experience, about disconnecting from the world to pursue a creative pursuit, not to paint something new but to create a playful way for his friends to connect. So now, his song, about a game, has been honored in a crossword. Quite fitting.
Loved this.

If I ever visit Chicago properly, I'll check out the museums, skipping those dedicated to modem art though, as I just can't appreciate it (to be honest, I don't see the "art" element in much of modern art, which is on me, probably, rather than the art itself).

@Andrzej
This is a painting really worth seeing. It's one where the scale and execution are really overwhelming. And looking at it, you can see why Seurat must have been completely dedicated AKA crazy to complete it. 
It took him two years as his style of painting, /pointillism/, consisted of applying millions of tiny dots to cover the 81" x 120" (6.75 √ó 10 ft.; ~2.1m x 3.1m) canvas and create the images.
Sondheim's play uses actors and cutouts to embody the figures in the painting and the knockout first-act curtain has all of them moving into the positions they occupy in the painting, so they form a living tableau.

@SBK

I'm looking at a photo of the painting and it doesn't grab me, artistically. I can appreciate it took guts to paint like that in those conservative times, and I'm glad people started daring to be different back then, because that led to the creation of a world in which Andrzej can freely be who he is. It's an historic work, like many others in the day. But it doesn't speak to me, personally. I can understand what you and others see in it, mind you. I *understand* the appeal. I just don't share it. This distinguishes works of Seurat, say, from some other artists the supposed greatness of whose oeuvre I will never understand.

For centuries people believed ducks (or was it geese?) spent winters under the ice. Given the modern approach to science in some places, this will probably re-enter school curricula!

My favorite fact about storks in not a fact at all. Bear with me, I'll get there after a bit of backrounding. Poles love storks. In fact, they could be considered our national bird, along with the eagle, which in turn is our official emblem. These days we all know they migrate to Africa in the winter, sure. But - and we're getting to the non-fact now - as it was presented in primary school to me, I thought for the longest time storks lived *only* in Poland in the summer. Can you imagine my surprise when I saw storks on my first foreign vacation? That must have been one of my life's first and biggest mindf___s.

And another fun fact about storks - Musk's AI will generate an image of one in whatever sick circumstances you wish!
@Andrzej I‚Äôm dying to know what ‚Äúthe longest time‚Äù means! I‚Äôm wondering if you were 8 or 48 before you found out storks were not exclusively Polish!

@Petrol

I like to be surrounded by an aura of mystery so I'll leave you guessing!

In a similar vein:

My father was born in a village in northern Mazovia. All the people went to church there back then (and pretty much still do these days). This being simple, Polish and Catholic religiosity, nobody really understood all the rites or all the the words of the priest, and this was especially true for children. One of the lines in the creed goes like this:

Ukrzy≈ºowany r√≥wnie≈º za nas, pod Ponckim Pi≈Çatem zosta≈Ç umƒôczony i pogrzebany

(For our sake he was crucified under Pontius Pilate, he suffered death and was buried)

Now, as a kid my father kept interpreting "pod Ponckim Pi≈Çatem" ("under Pontius Pilate") as "pod p≈Ço≈Ñskim powiatem" - which makes perfect sense in Poland and means... "in the P≈Ço≈Ñsk county" - P≈Ço≈Ñsk county bordered on Ciechan√≥w county, where dad lived. And thus dad believed for years that Mary and Jesus were Polish, and had lived nearby.

I thought you were going to tell that STORKS are beloved, and that a nest atop one's house is a lucky sign (a la the Netherlands, where one can see the huge nests waiting for the migrating birds to return.)  But your story is wonderful!  (As is the next one below!)

@Asher B. I sometimes find the theme of the puzzle ponderous or uninteresting, but Sondheim is one of the greatest composers and lyricists in American musical history, responsible for creating or contributing to twenty or so musical productions in NYC in a career spanning eight decades.  A Pulitzer Prize winning genius, he also happened to be an avid puzzler and constructor of cryptic crosswords in his own right. In fact, he contributed the puzzle to the debut issue of New York Magazine in 1968, introducing cryptics to a wider audience.  While you may be unaware of his work and legacy, or even uninterested, to me Sondheim is the amalgam of thee elements: music that is brilliant in its compositional construction and harmonic intention, married to deftly wrought lyrics dripping with an uncompromisingly playful use of language, and finally (maybe above all else) the quintessential spirit of New York itself.  For my money, there‚Äôs no more apt, or better a theme for a NYT crossword puzzle than Stephen Sondheim.
